context: When the news arrived in England it caused an outcry. In response, a combined bounty of <a1_0><b7_0>£1,000<b7_0/><a1_0/> was offered for <a0_0><b6_0>Every<b6_0/><a0_0/>'s capture by the <a3_0><b8_0>Privy Council<b8_0/><a3_0/> and East India Company, leading to the first worldwide <a2_0>manhunt<a2_0/> in recorded history. The plunder of Aurangzeb's treasure ship had serious consequences for the English East India Company. The furious <a4_0><b9_0>Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb<b9_0/><a4_0/> ordered Sidi Yaqub and Nawab Daud Khan to attack and close four of the company's factories in India and imprison their officers, who were almost lynched by a mob of angry Mughals, blaming them for their countryman's depredations, and threatened to put an end to all English trading in India. To appease Emperor Aurangzeb and particularly his Grand Vizier Asad Khan, Parliament exempted Every from all of the <a5_0>Acts of Grace<a5_0/> (pardons) and amnesties it would subsequently issue to other pirates.
